### Sampling and Testing Problems

- Unrepresentative Data Sets

The validity of statistical analysis depends on the extent to which the sample/data set on which the analysis is performed is representative of the entire population for which the analyst is concerned. 

When a sample, sub-sample, or data set is a biased representation of population, then statistical tests may be unreliable.

A bias is when sample is obtained/selected in a manner that systematically favors inclusion of observations with particular characteristics that affect the statistical analysis.

Selection bias is a distortion in relevant sample characteristics from characteristics of population, caused by sampling method of selection/inclusion. 

If selection bias originates from decision of fund managers to report or not to report their returns, then the bias is a self‐selection bias.

Survivorship bias is where sample is limited to observations that continue to exist through the end of the period of study.

- Data Mining vs Data Dredging

Data mining refers to vigorous use of data to uncover valid relationships.

The idea is that by using a variety of well‐designed statistical tests and exploring a number of data sources, analysts may uncover previously missed relationships. 

Data dredging/snooping refers to overuse and misuse of statistical tests to identify historical patterns. 

The difference is that data dredging involves performing too many tests, especially regarding historical relationships for which there are not a priori reasons for believing that the relationships reflect true causality. 

The problem with data dredging is not so much the number of tests performed as the failure to take the number of tests performed into account when analyzing the results.

Any empirical results should be analyzed not only in context of other research and economic reasoning but also through understanding of how many tests have been performed. 

Not only can this information be difficult to obtain/estimate, but it may also be intentionally masked by researchers attempting to bolster a particular view.

- Backtesting and Backfilling

Backtesting is use of historical data to test a strategy that was developed subsequent to observation of the data. 

Backtesting is valid method of obtaining information on the historical risk and return of a strategy, which can be used as an indication of the strategy's potential going forward. 

Backtesting combined with data dredging and numerous strategies can generate false indications of future returns. 

The reason is the strategy identified as most successful in the past is its performance driven by luck. 

One must be careful of allocating funds to investment managers who choose to report backtested results of their new model rather than actual returns of the disappointing old model that traded client money in real time.

Backtesting is dangerous when model involves overfitting. Overfitting is using too many parameters to fit a model very closely to data over some past time frame. 

Models that have been overfit tend to have a smaller chance of fitting future data than a model using fewer and more generalized parameters.

In alternative investments, backfilling refers to insertion of actual trading record of an investment into database when that trading record predates the entry of the investment into the database.

Backfilling of actual results can be appropriate technique, especially when done with full disclosure and when there is reasonable basis to believe that results will not create a substantial bias or deception. 

Data sets of investment fund returns sometimes include past actual results of funds in the data set when the sample of funds being included is not being assembled on the basis of past investment results. 

The danger with backfilling is backfill bias. 
Backfill bias (instant history bias) is when the funds, returns, and strategies being added to a data set are not representative of the universe of fund managers, fund returns, and fund strategies.

Instead, additions would generate an upward return bias because it'd be likely that data set would disproportionately add returns of successful funds that are more likely to survive and that may be more likely to want to publicize their results.

Backfilling can also refer to use of hypothetical data from backtesting. 

In investments in general, backfilling refers to the insertion of hypothetical trading results into a summary of an investment opportunity. 

A reason that backfilling rarely refers to inclusion of hypothetical trading results in the case of alternative investments that often focus on active trading strategies, in which hypothetical trading results would be highly discretionary and would be unsuited to hypothetical backfilling.

Backfilling can be deceptive even with innocent intentions. 

Often investors change/evolve their strategies as time passes, conditions change, and performance declines. 

Traders are likely to adapt their strategies in response to poor performance.

An investor who backtests a revised trading strategy and backfills the hypothetical performance into the track record of the current and revised strategy is clearly providing a biased indication of forward‐looking performance. 

The indication would be especially biased if revision in the strategy were in response to data from the same time interval on which the backfilling was performed.

- Cherry‐Picking and Chumming

Cherry‐picking is the concept of extracting/publicizing only those results that support a particular viewpoint

Chumming is a fishing term used to describe scattering pieces of cheap fish into the water as bait to attract larger fish to catch. 

In investments, this term is the practice of unscrupulous investment managers broadcasting a variety of predictions in the hope that some of them will turn out to be correct and thus be viewed as an indication of skill.

NB: Attractive results are not interpreted in the context of total number of experiments being conducted.
